metaphor.core: George Orwell's '1984' provides a powerful metaphor for controlled components in React. The Party's totalitarian control over information and reality, enforced by telescreens and the Ministry of Truth, mirrors how controlled components keep input elements synchronized with a single source of truth (React state), ensuring data consistency and preventing discrepancies.

mapping.reactConcept: Uncontrolled component with its own internal DOM state, leading to potential desynchronization with application state
The `value` prop of a controlled component, always reflecting the React state
The single source of truth in React state for input elements
The `onChange` handler of a controlled component, intercepting user input to validate, transform, or reject changes before updating state
Data desynchronization bugs and loss of user input when uncontrolled components are not properly managed
The benefit of controlled components: always-in-sync UI and state, enabling real-time validation, formatting, and complex form logic

metaphor.narrativeArc: The module follows Winston's struggle with the 'lag of truth' where his private diary (uncontrolled input) conflicts with the Party's official record (application state), leading to errors. He then encounters the Party's 'clear' terminal (controlled input) where every keystroke is intercepted and validated, forcing conformity to a single truth. This narrative arc demonstrates the problems of uncontrolled components and the benefits of controlled components for data consistency, validation, and a seamless user experience.

problems: Data desynchronization between DOM and React state
Difficulty with real-time validation and formatting
Manual DOM manipulation for input values

chapters.title: The Forbidden Diary
chapters.focus: Introduces uncontrolled components, where the DOM manages its own state, leading to discrepancies with application state.

chapters.title: The Lag of Truth
chapters.focus: Demonstrates the problems and anti-patterns of uncontrolled inputs, such as data desynchronization and validation failures.

chapters.title: The Party's Clarity
chapters.focus: Explains and demonstrates controlled components, where React state is the single source of truth, enabling real-time validation and transformation.

chapters.title: Two Systems, One Truth
chapters.focus: Compares uncontrolled vs. controlled components side-by-side, highlighting data flow and event handling differences.

chapters.title: Loving Big Brother's State
chapters.focus: Summarizes the advantages of controlled components for complex form logic, data integrity, and a predictable user experience.
